comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Joe Duffy did a feature last week on a tenement on Fenian St that collapsed in 1963 killing two children (50 years ago last Wednesday) irishphotoarchive.photoshelter.com/gallery/1963-Dublin-te... It was obviously an emotive issue at the time.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's the podcast www.rte.ie/radio1/liveline/programmes/2013/0612/456225-li...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Corporation-owned properties were let fall into such a state of disrepair that demolition was the only option. This was at a time when there was very little regulation regarding building & planning standards and Georgian architecture was not valued very much.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: BTW Guinness were using kangaroos in their ads in 1956 (to coincide with the Melbourne Olympics presumably) www.youtube.com/watch?v=P36ZQLAwD3g

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: ..and had being using them as early as 1947 as part of their zookeeper series www.guinness.com/en-au/Adsdetails.html?adid=31

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Very sad indeed! I helped a reader here a couple of years ago research contemporary newspaper reports of the Fenian Street collapse - he had relatives involved.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1964/03/05/00035.asp Dail Eireann 5th March 1964 ( May not relate to York street) Mr. Ryan: asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that furniture and household goods belonging to persons evicted from dangerous buildings by the Dublin Corporation and stored by the Corporation have been damaged; what steps will be taken to prevent further damage by dampness and cold; and whether compensation will be paid by the Corporation to persons suffering loss by reason of the Corporation's neglect.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1964/06/02/00020.asp 2nd June 1964 Dail Eireann ( May not relate to York street) Mr. Mullen: and Mr. Corish asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware that, in a number of cases where tenants have been evicted from buildings declared dangerous in Dublin, small shopkeepers have been evicted from their premises which were located in these buildings; and that they have been offered no alternative shop sites or compensation; and whether, in view of the fact that these shopkeepers have been totally deprived of their only means of livelihood by the loss of their premises, he will take steps to enable Dublin Corporation to compensate them adequately for their loss.

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Great photo!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Had a quick look in the newspapers. Thinking this may have been in June or July 1964, because the Irish Times has a photo on Wednesday 22 July with the caption:
Evicted tenants of York street and Hogan place pictured outside the Russell Hotel, St. Stephen's Green, before they began a protest parade through the city centre.
(Again, God Bless the Corporation signs feature in that photo) On Saturday, 25 July 1964, the Irish Times has a tiny article about Quickening Pace of City's Changing Face and the very last sentence reads:
Site clearance is now taking place at York street where the Corporation may be able to build 70 flats.
Meanwhile, the Irish Independent reported on a collapsing tenement on Lower Gardiner Street on Wednesday, 17 June 1964, and so on and so forth, so I'm stopping now, because I'm getting depressed...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 

books.google.ie/books?isbn=1902448936

Here they talk about the Introduction of the Local Government (Sanitary Services) Act, 1964 (28th July) they say it was adopted following an accident where a Dublin building collapsed causing several deaths. 

perhaps this is to do with your Irish Indo piece?

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Perhaps so, I'd have to check it again. Though I think people escaped alive from that one. Maybe the Fenian Street Collapse from the year before?
